preparation_steps: Test soil pH to 6.0-7.0 using digital meter 2-3 weeks before planting
Work 2-3 inches compost into top 8 inches soil when temperature reaches 50°F
Choose location with full sun receiving 6-8 hours direct sunlight daily
planting_steps: Start pineapple seeds indoors 6-8 weeks before 2025-05-10 at 70-75°F soil temperature
Sow seeds 1.5 inches deep with 18 inch spacing between plants
Transplant outdoors 2 weeks after 2025-05-10 when nighttime temperatures stay above 50°F
care_instructions: Water pineapple deeply 1-1.5 inches per week checking soil moisture 2 inches deep every 3 days
Apply 10-10-10 fertilizer at 2 tablespoons per plant every 3 weeks starting 2 weeks after transplant
Mulch with 2-3 inches organic matter keeping 6 inches away from plant stem
pest_management: Inspect pineapple weekly for common zone 4a-6a pests from May through September
Apply neem oil spray at 2 tablespoons per gallon water every 14 days if pests detected
Use floating row covers first 3 weeks after transplant to prevent early season pest damage
harvest_instructions: Begin harvesting pineapple approximately 120 days after transplant when fruits reach full size
Harvest in early morning 6-8 AM when temperatures below 75°F for best quality and flavor
Cut stems with clean sharp shears 1/4 inch above leaf node to encourage continued production
storage_tips: Store fresh pineapple at 55-60°F with 85% humidity for maximum 7-10 days after harvest
Blanch and freeze within 24 hours of harvest - maintains quality for 8-12 months in freezer
Preserve excess using canning or dehydrating methods appropriate for fruit type

plant_groupings.spacing_notes: Pineapples can be spaced 18 inches apart to allow for proper growth and air circulation. Consider grouping them in a triangular formation to maximize space.

general_tips: Pineapple plants prefer well-draining soil with a pH between 5.5 and 6.5, so test your soil before planting.
In Moncton's cold climate, it's best to grow pineapple as an indoor plant or in a greenhouse until the temperature warms up in late spring.
Choose a variety of pineapple that is resistant to frost, such as 'Smooth Cayenne' or 'Red Spanish', for better success in your garden.
Pineapple plants require full sun to produce fruit, so choose a location with direct sunlight for at least 6 hours a day.
Water your pineapple plant regularly, but make sure the soil isn't waterlogged. Pineapples are sensitive to root rot and can be susceptible to fungal diseases in wet conditions.
Fertilize your pineapple plant with a balanced fertilizer (10-10-10) during the growing season (April to September), following the manufacturer's instructions for application rates.
